articles.headline: Trump Team’s Shifts Jolt Some Allies and Soothe Others
articles.snippet: Remarks by the president cut in two directions, appearing to undermine his secretary of state on Qatar, but reassuring NATO allies by vowing to defend them.
articles.abstract: Remarks by the president cut in two directions, appearing to undermine his secretary of state on Qatar, but reassuring NATO allies by vowing to defend them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump scrambled American diplomacy on two fronts on Friday, delivering a stinging rebuke of Qatar at the very moment his secretary of state was trying to mend fences in the Persian Gulf, while at the same time reaffirming support for NATO two weeks after he had declined to do so.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: How Badly Must a C.E.O. Behave Before His Pay Is Clawed Back?
articles.snippet: A United Airlines shareholder filed a suit over the $28.6 million paid to the former chief executive Jeffery A. Smisek, who left in a bribery scandal.
articles.abstract: A United Airlines shareholder filed a suit over the $28.6 million paid to the former chief executive Jeffery A. Smisek, who left in a bribery scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Airlines’ contempt for customers was on full display in April, when it dragged a passenger from an overbooked plane, bloodying him in the process.

articles.headline: Jeremy Corbyn Lost U.K. Election, but Is Still Its Biggest Winner
articles.snippet: Despite being derided as hopeless and hapless, the Labour leader re-energized his party in the vote Thursday, and altered the landscape of British politics.
articles.abstract: Despite being derided as hopeless and hapless, the Labour leader re-energized his party in the vote Thursday, and altered the landscape of British politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was a scathing put-down. “He can lead a protest, I’m leading the country,” Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain said about the leader of the opposition Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Drivers Head Into Summer With a Gift at the Gas Pump
articles.snippet: The average nationwide gasoline price on Friday was the lowest for this time of year since 2005, despite OPEC cutbacks and Middle East tensions.
articles.abstract: The average nationwide gasoline price on Friday was the lowest for this time of year since 2005, despite OPEC cutbacks and Middle East tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Looking for an excuse to pack up the car for a road trip this weekend?

articles.headline: Pandora, Faded Star of Online Music, Gets Cash Infusion From Sirius XM
articles.snippet: Once a pioneer in the streaming music business, Pandora is facing stiff competition from Spotify and Apple Music, among others. Now it has turned to the satellite radio provider for help.
articles.abstract: Once a pioneer in the streaming music business, Pandora is facing stiff competition from Spotify and Apple Music, among others. Now it has turned to the satellite radio provider for help.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pandora was early to the online music business, introducing a free internet radio service just a few years after Apple started iTunes and enjoying a successful debut as a public company.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Masquerading as Reporter, Assassin Hunted Putin Foes in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Pretending to be a reporter for Le Monde, the assassin pulled a gun and fired during an interview with two well-known soldiers in the war against separatists in eastern Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Pretending to be a reporter for Le Monde, the assassin pulled a gun and fired during an interview with two well-known soldiers in the war against separatists in eastern Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukrainians have long struggled with fake news from Russia, but last week, they discovered something even more insidious: a fake journalist.

articles.headline: Settlements for Company Sins Can No Longer Aid Other Projects, Sessions Says
articles.snippet: The attorney general signed an order this week to end the practice of requiring corporate wrongdoers to make payments to outside groups or causes.
articles.abstract: The attorney general signed an order this week to end the practice of requiring corporate wrongdoers to make payments to outside groups or causes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When companies settle claims of wrongdoing, they are often compelled to pay for environmental or community development projects as well as pay fines and direct compensation to victims. Sometimes the third-party payments are only marginally related to the damages caused by the company’s actions.
articles.byline: By Tatiana Schlossberg and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Culture Clash at a Chinese-Owned Plant in Ohio
articles.snippet: A town welcomed an investment in a glass factory employing more than 1,500, but tensions have arisen over safety, foreign control and culture clashes.
articles.abstract: A town welcomed an investment in a glass factory employing more than 1,500, but tensions have arisen over safety, foreign control and culture clashes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORAINE, Ohio — When a giant Chinese glassmaker arrived here in 2014 and began spending what would become more than a half-billion dollars to fix up an abandoned General Motors plant, it seemed like a tale from opposite land: The Chinese are supposedly stealing American jobs — as no less an authority than President Trump has pointed out.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Religious Liberals Sat Out of Politics for 40 Years. Now They Want in the Game.
articles.snippet: Faith leaders whose politics fall to the left of center are getting more involved in politics to fight against President Trump’s policies.
articles.abstract: Faith leaders whose politics fall to the left of center are getting more involved in politics to fight against President Trump’s policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Nashville, a crowd of ministers carrying palm fronds occupied the governor’s office during Holy Week, demanding the expansion of Medicaid to cover more of the uninsured. In California and 16 other states, an interfaith network has organized thousands of volunteers to swoop into action when immigrants are arrested or houses of worship are vandalized.

articles.headline: Opioid Dealers Embrace the Dark Web to Send Deadly Drugs by Mail
articles.snippet: Anonymous online sales are surging, and people are dying. Despite dozens of arrests, new merchants — many based in Asia — quickly pop up.
articles.abstract: Anonymous online sales are surging, and people are dying. Despite dozens of arrests, new merchants — many based in Asia — quickly pop up.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the nation’s opioid crisis worsens, the authorities are confronting a resurgent, unruly player in the illicit trade of the deadly drugs, one that threatens to be even more formidable than the cartels.

articles.headline: Venezuela Musicians Rise Up After Violist, 18, Is Killed at Protest
articles.snippet: Political unrest is testing the loyalties of many who have benefited from the socialist-oriented government, including musicians outraged by the shooting of an unarmed teenager.
articles.abstract: Political unrest is testing the loyalties of many who have benefited from the socialist-oriented government, including musicians outraged by the shooting of an unarmed teenager.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Armando Cañizales left his viola at home that day.
articles.byline: By Ana Vanessa Herrero and Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: Trump-Comey Feud Eclipses a Warning on Russia: ‘They Will Be Back’
articles.snippet: Security experts worry that the focus on the battle between the president and the former F.B.I. director will divert attention from Russian intervention.
articles.abstract: Security experts worry that the focus on the battle between the president and the former F.B.I. director will divert attention from Russian intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lost in the showdown between President Trump and James B. Comey that played out this past week was a chilling threat to the United States. Mr. Comey, the former director of the F.B.I., testified that the Russians had not only intervened in last year’s election, but would try to do it again.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Long Before It Lost Turf, ISIS Was Already Targeting Britain
articles.snippet: The Islamic State has been focused for years on attacking Britain and Iran. The recent assaults in London and Tehran make it clear the group never gave up on that goal.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State has been focused for years on attacking Britain and Iran. The recent assaults in London and Tehran make it clear the group never gave up on that goal.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the weeks after Islamic State operatives struck Paris in November 2015, the group released a prerecorded video of the killers. They stared into the camera, waved serrated knives, raged at the West and specifically warned Britain: You’re next. Footage showed scenes of London through a gunsight.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Laure Fourquet

articles.headline: For Britain, Political Stability Is a Quaint Relic
articles.snippet: Voters, no longer content with the old, predictable divisions of class and regional identity, must be wooed by programs and personalities.
articles.abstract: Voters, no longer content with the old, predictable divisions of class and regional identity, must be wooed by programs and personalities.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a little more than two years, Britain has had two general elections and a nationwide referendum. Each time, the politicians, pollsters, betting markets, political scientists and commentators have gotten it wrong.

articles.headline: Democrats in Split-Screen: The Base Wants It All. The Party Wants to Win.
articles.snippet: A drawn-out Democratic struggle between liberals and pragmatists could spill into primaries and disrupt the party’s path to a majority.
articles.abstract: A drawn-out Democratic struggle between liberals and pragmatists could spill into primaries and disrupt the party’s path to a majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNWOODY, Ga. — Democrats are facing a widening breach in their party, as liberal activists dream of transforming the health care system and impeaching President Trump, while candidates in hard-fought elections ask wary voters merely for a fresh chance at governing.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Uber Weighs Leave of Absence for Chief Executive
articles.snippet: The board is considering Travis Kalanick’s future and the recommendations of Eric H. Holder Jr.’s investigation into the company’s culture.
articles.abstract: The board is considering Travis Kalanick’s future and the recommendations of Eric H. Holder Jr.’s investigation into the company’s culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facing accusations that Uber executives turned a blind eye to sexual harassment and other corporate misbehavior, the ride-hailing service’s board moved on Sunday to shake up the company’s leadership, ahead of the release this week of an investigation’s findings on its troubled culture.

articles.headline: Role of Trump’s Personal Lawyer Blurs Public and Private Lines
articles.snippet: Marc E. Kasowitz, the president’s private lawyer, has counseled administration staff and exerted broader influence over legal strategy.
articles.abstract: Marc E. Kasowitz, the president’s private lawyer, has counseled administration staff and exerted broader influence over legal strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new figure has swept through the West Wing lately, a man with silver hair combed back across his head, rimless glasses perched on his nose, a white handkerchief tucked neatly into his suit pocket, a taste for legal pugilism and an uncertain role in a building confronted by a host of political and legal threats.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Reviving a Lost Language of Canada Through Film
articles.snippet: The first Haida-language feature film is being shot on Canada’s west coast. The biggest challenge? Fewer than 20 people worldwide speak Haida fluently.
articles.abstract: The first Haida-language feature film is being shot on Canada’s west coast. The biggest challenge? Fewer than 20 people worldwide speak Haida fluently.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIELLEN, British Columbia — Speaking Haida for the first time in more than 60 years looked painful. Sphenia Jones’s cheeks glistened with sweat, and her eyes clenched shut. She tried again to produce the forgotten raspy echo of the Haida k’, and again she failed. Then she smiled broadly.

articles.headline: Toasting the Ad Industry and a Book Predicting Its Doom
articles.snippet: At a salute for “The End of Advertising” by the former ad executive Andrew Essex, those in the industry clung to the belief that creativity would win the day.
articles.abstract: At a salute for “The End of Advertising” by the former ad executive Andrew Essex, those in the industry clung to the belief that creativity would win the day.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York media types aren’t quick to pass up a party, even one celebrating a book that predicts their demise.

articles.headline: Flexibility That A.C.A. Lent to Work Force Is Threatened by G.O.P. Plan
articles.snippet: People in transition because of layoffs, moves, illness or new ventures turned to Obamacare’s marketplaces as a stopgap, but that option may soon be gone.
articles.abstract: People in transition because of layoffs, moves, illness or new ventures turned to Obamacare’s marketplaces as a stopgap, but that option may soon be gone.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, millions of middle- and working-class Americans have moved from job to job, some staying with one company for shorter stints or shifting careers midstream.

articles.headline: In Watergate, One Set of Facts. In Trump Era, Take Your Pick.
articles.snippet: Rival versions of the Trump-Russia scandal are fighting for narrative supremacy, leaving news veterans wondering, “What if Watergate happened now?”
articles.abstract: Rival versions of the Trump-Russia scandal are fighting for narrative supremacy, leaving news veterans wondering, “What if Watergate happened now?”
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a question that has hung out there throughout our hyper-driven, hyper-divided media era: What would Watergate look like if it were to happen now?

articles.headline: Preparing for ‘Brexit,’ Britons Face Economic Pinch at Home
articles.snippet: In a tumultuous period of political uncertainty, Britain’s economy is markedly slowing and consumers are grappling with rising prices.
articles.abstract: In a tumultuous period of political uncertainty, Britain’s economy is markedly slowing and consumers are grappling with rising prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Right about now, Eddie Stamton, a construction worker, would normally be making preparations to jet off to a sandy stretch of the Mediterranean for a summer holiday. Not this year.

articles.headline: Across Russia, Protesters Heed Navalny’s Anti-Kremlin Rallying Cry
articles.snippet: Aleksei A. Navalny, a leading Putin critic, was detained outside his home in Moscow as an extraordinary wave of antigovernment protests swept across Russia.
articles.abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny, a leading Putin critic, was detained outside his home in Moscow as an extraordinary wave of antigovernment protests swept across Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — An extraordinary wave of antigovernment protests swept across Russia on Monday, as thousands of demonstrators gathered in more than 100 cities to denounce corruption and political stagnation despite official attempts to stifle the expression of outrage.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: A Stagnant General Electric Will Replace the C.E.O. Who Transformed It
articles.snippet: The industrial giant, whose jet engines propel air travelers and whose generators light millions of households, declared that it would be installing its first new leader in 16 years.
articles.abstract: The industrial giant, whose jet engines propel air travelers and whose generators light millions of households, declared that it would be installing its first new leader in 16 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric, the 125-year-old industrial giant whose jet engines propel air travelers around the globe and whose electrical generators light millions of households, declared on Monday that it would be installing its first new leader in 16 years.
